thread.title: Perth parents at war with Labor over 'stifling, sterile' high-rise CBD school plan
thread.title_full: Perth parents at war with Labor over 'stifling, sterile' high-rise CBD school plan

author: Laura Gartry
title: Perth parents at war with Labor over 'stifling, sterile' high-rise CBD school plan
text:
Map: Perth 6000 
WA Labor's election commitment to move students from the state's only academically selective school to a high-rise building is being met with fierce opposition from hundreds of parents and alumni. 
Under the proposal, students from Perth Modern School, located in Subiaco, would be relocated to a new school — leaving the old site to become a public secondary school by 2020. 
The proposed new school, "Perth Academic College" would be located at the Perth City Link development. 
The plan would also scrap the State Government's plans for the new City Beach College in the western suburbs, which is designed to cater growing population pressures in the area . 
A website and Facebook page called Save Perth Modern School has been actively encouraging parents to lobby their Labor candidate over the issue ahead of the election. 
More than 1,000 people have signed a Change.org petition against the proposal, which accuses Labor of planning to "move these children into the stifling, adult-oriented CBD where they can begin their career in sterile, high-rise captivity at age 11". 
Spokeswoman for the Save the Perth Modern School group Emma Gregory, who is a parent of grade seven student, said there had been "zero consultation" with parents over the plan. 
"My first response was disbelief, to extreme concern building to absolute outrage," she said. 
"It is taking a vibrant and dynamic centre for excellence, a perfectly well functioning school and taking a huge gamble." 
She said parents were concerned about lack of outdoor green space and safety issues for students in the Northbridge. 
Emails sent to parents, seen by the ABC, suggest the city is unsafe. 
"I work right there and literally step over remnants of stinking drunkenness, commiserate with homelessness (sic) on the paths in the morning, step around drug deals in broad daylight — is that what he wants for (sic) our children to be exposed to???" one of the emails reads. 
Ms Gregory said the group would fight the proposal up until the election and beyond if need be. Centrally located school 'best services need' 
Labor's education spokeswoman, Sue Ellery, said it made sense for the school to be centrally located. 
"The building at the CBD site will be purpose-built, it will have outdoor green space on every floor," she said. 
Ms Ellery said some of parents that had written to her were "ill-informed" about the proposal. 
"Perhaps some of them have not actually read the policy document because some of the suggestions that have been made are far from the truth," she said. 
"Some of the comments have been a bit [ill-informed] really, as if design decisions have been made already, when that is not the case. 
"It couldn't possibly be the case because we are not elected." 
Ms Ellery said she would not meet with the Save the Perth Modern School group before the election. 
"I've met with representatives of the P&C and alumni already, if we are elected I am happy to engage with the school community on the design of the new site and on the name of the new school," she said. 
Education Minister Peter Collier said Labor's policy was based entirely on political expediency. 
"Not what is right from an educational perspective," he said. 
"They are decimating — they are napalming Perth Modern School. 
"A school with a magnificent history, not just academically but culturally and for the community. They completely ignored everyone." Western suburbs parents also unhappy Photo: James Fuller's two daughters Chloe (l) and Freya go to City Beach primary school. (ABC News: Laura Gartry) 
Parent's from the western suburbs are also unhappy with the decision to scrap the new City Beach College. 
The Liberal National Government pledged $84 million to upgrade the site of the former City Beach High School to ease growing enrolment pressure in Perth's western suburbs. 
The original City Beach High School was closed in 2005, and the remaining schools servicing the western suburbs are bursting at the seams. 
Churchlands Senior High School's student body grew from 1,443 in 2011 to 2,500 last year. Shenton College has grown to more than 1,900 students. 
'We need a Highschool' group spokesman James Fuller, who has two children at City Beach school, said he had not seen any data that supported the idea the CBD school would reduce pressure on the area. 
"The feeling is, it is a play for some of the marginal seats like Perth and Mount Lawley rather than a solid education policy," he said. 
Ms Ellery said a Labor government would make a decision on the future of the City Beach site if elected.
